clinical_study.brief_title: Major Pelvic Hemorrhage in Complex Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Management and Outcomes of Major Pelvic Hemorrhage in Patients Undergoing Complex Abdomino-Pelvic Surgery: A Cohort Study

brief_summary.textblock: Hemorrhage is a challenging complication of pelvic surgery. In this study, the investigators aimed to analyze the causes, management, and outcomes of major pelvic hemorrhage in patients undergoing complex abdomino-pelvic surgery. Participants who had a major intraoperative pelvic hemorrhage during complex abdomino-pelvic surgery at 11 tertiary referral centers were included. Participant characteristics, causes of hemorrhage, management strategies, and outcomes including morbidity and mortality analyses were evaluated.

primary_outcome.description: Complication rate (Number of participants who had a complication divided by total number of participants)

arm_group.description: Patients who had pelvic hemorrhage during complex abdomino-pelvic surgery

intervention.intervention_name: Stopping of pelvic bleeding via several surgical methods
intervention.description: Those surgical methods were pelvic packing, electrocautery, energy devices, suturing, fastener, muscle welding, procoagulant chemicals, and combination of those

study_pop.textblock: Patient operated for complex abdominopelvic surgery including radical oncologic operations for the primary advanced or recurrent carcinoma of pelvic organs, pelvic cytoreduction, revisional/redo operations for failed ileal/colonic pouches, repair of the entero-enteral, entero-cutaneous, entero-vesical and entero-vaginal fistulas who had presacral bleeding in centers which had over 225 colorectal cases per year were included. Major pelvic bleeding is defined as symptomatic bleeding originating from pelvis, bleeding leading to transfusion of ≥2 units of whole blood or packed red cells; surgical site bleeding that requires a second intervention; or surgical site bleeding that is unexpected and prolonged and/or sufficiently large to cause hemodynamic instability with an associated decrease in hemoglobin ≥20 g/L.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who had major pelvic bleeding during complex abdominopelvic surgery
- Patients operated in hospitals where over 225 colorectal cases were performed every year
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients operated for palliative intent
